awd_titl_txt: Chemistry of Strained Molecules with Radially Conjugated Pi Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Ramesh Jasti of the University of Oregon (UO) is studying the synthesis, chemical reactivity, and properties of molecular fragments of carbon nanotubes. These macrocyclic synthetic targets are of fundamental interest for their structural, photophysical and electronic properties, and supramolecular chemistry, as well as their potential to lead to the uniform synthesis of carbon nanotubes. This research program, deeply rooted in organic synthesis and new synthetic methods, is also relevant to the fields of materials science, biology, and physics. The PI’s choice of challenging synthetic targets provides graduate and undergraduate students with a thorough background in synthetic organic strategy, methodology development, and reaction mechanism. In addition, these targets provide students opportunities to collaborate with physicists, engineers, and theorists to measure, utilize, and understand the physical properties of the newly created precision nanomaterials.  

Molecules with radially oriented pi-systems have been appreciated by chemists for decades, but have recently undergone a renaissance in that new developments in synthetic methodology have rendered what were previously mostly theoretical curiosities into now accessible structures. In this next grant period, the Jasti research group aims to continue to push the synthetic boundaries to the growing class of strained macrocycles with radially conjugated pi systems. Specifically, new pi-extended belt-like structures, twisted aromatics, and nitrogen doped nanohoops are all targeted in this grant cycle. In addition, strain promoted reactions of alkyne embedded nanohoops will be investigated as a rapid synthetic strategy to diversify this class of molecules. The methods and strategies developed for the targeted structures will be applicable to other types of polyaromatic hydrocarbons and new graphitic materials (not just the specific ones in this proposal) and therefore are of high intellectual merit. The PI also partners with the UO Summer Science program to provide educational experiences that highlight interdisciplinary research and hands-on science to groups of students that are traditionally underserved in the state of Oregon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Molecules with radially oriented pi-systems have long captured the interest of chemists. However, recent advancements in synthetic methodologies have transformed these once largely theoretical curiosities into accessible and intriguing structures. These molecules are of fundamental interest due to their structural, photophysical, and electronic properties, as well as their applications in supramolecular chemistry and their potential to enable the uniform synthesis of novel carbon nanomaterials. Expanding synthetic approaches to diversify this class of structures and their properties remains highly desirable.

During the last grant period, the Jasti group focused on developing new modes of reactivity applicable to these carbon nanostructures. One approach involved creating synthetic methodologies to prepare strained nanohoops with embedded alkyne functionalities. We hypothesized that these structures would exhibit strain-promoted reactivity. To explore this phenomenon, we embedded alkynes into nanohoops of varying sizes and measured their reaction rates with azides. These reactions proved to be highly efficient, required no copper catalyst, and preserved the optoelectronic properties of the parent nanohoops. Additionally, we envisioned that these strained molecules could participate in other transformations, such as cyclotrimerizations, and demonstrated that such reactions yielded molecules with fluorescence brightness three times greater than the parent nanohoop.

In another effort, we pursued the generation of stable pyridinium-like structures using C-H activation chemistry. These resulting compounds exhibited low-lying LUMOs, and the approach provided a straightforward, one-step method to create functionalized nanohoops with predictable regiochemistry. Furthermore, we utilized nucleophilic substitution chemistry to generate catechol-like nanohoops capable of coordinating metals such as ruthenium. This work significantly broadened the types of structures that could be synthesized and expanded their resulting properties.

From a broader impact perspective, a central mission of this grant was to provide educational opportunities that promote interdisciplinary science to a diverse group of students. Over the course of the grant period, four doctoral students contributed to the project and three have since earned their PhDs. Additionally, four undergraduates participated in various aspects of the research and have earned their undergraduate degrees. The principal investigator also developed a summer bridge program to support underrepresented incoming freshmen interested in chemistry.

One of the overarching goals of our work was to establish synthetic methods and strategies that could be broadly applied beyond the initial targets. Copper-free click chemistry, for example, enables nanohoops to be conjugated with biomolecules and other materials, opening avenues for future exploration. We also anticipated that these conjugated molecules, with their unique geometric structures, would exhibit novel optoelectronic properties and applications. In one collaborative effort, we demonstrated that nanohoops can be integrated into materials for 3D printing. Specifically, we showed that biomaterials can be 3D printed with highly precise structures and rendered fluorescent by incorporating small amounts of nanohoops.

Numerous research groups worldwide have adopted our methods to prepare nanohoop-like structures and other nonplanar aromatics with unprecedented properties. Cycloparaphenylenes (CPPs) and their derivatives are being actively studied across disciplines including coordination chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, theoretical chemistry, photophysics, and, more recently, biology. The synthetic strategies and methods developed through this proposal will continue to influence a wide range of allied fields.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Ramesh Jasti
